name: Ceres
description: Ceres is the largest object in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter. It is the only dwarf planet located in the inner solar system and contains about a third of all mass in the asteroid belt.
funFacts: Ceres was the first asteroid ever discovered, in 1801.
It has a thin atmosphere and possible subsurface ocean.
NASA's Dawn spacecraft orbited Ceres from 2015-2018.
Bright spots on Ceres are salt deposits from an underground ocean.

name: Vesta
description: Vesta is the second-largest asteroid in the asteroid belt. It is one of the few asteroids visible to the naked eye and has a differentiated interior like a planet.
funFacts: Vesta is the brightest asteroid visible from Earth.
It has a giant crater called Rheasilvia at its south pole.
Meteorites from Vesta have landed on Earth.
NASA's Dawn spacecraft studied Vesta in 2011-2012.

name: Pallas
description: Pallas is the third-largest asteroid in the asteroid belt. Its highly inclined orbit makes it difficult to study with spacecraft.
funFacts: Pallas has the most tilted orbit of any large asteroid.
It was once considered a candidate for dwarf planet status.
Its surface is rich in silicates and iron.
No spacecraft has ever visited Pallas.

name: Hygiea
description: Hygiea is the fourth-largest asteroid in the main belt. It is nearly spherical and is being considered for dwarf planet classification.
funFacts: Hygiea may qualify as a dwarf planet due to its round shape.
It is the largest carbonaceous asteroid.
Named after the Greek goddess of health.
It's the largest member of the Hygiea family of asteroids.

name: Eros
description: Eros is one of the largest near-Earth asteroids. It was the first asteroid to be orbited and landed upon by a spacecraft (NEAR Shoemaker).
funFacts: NEAR Shoemaker spacecraft landed on Eros in 2001.
Eros has a peanut or banana-like shape.
It occasionally passes closer to the Sun than Mars.
Named after the Greek god of love.

name: Bennu
description: Bennu is a carbon-rich near-Earth asteroid. NASA's OSIRIS-REx mission collected samples from Bennu and returned them to Earth in 2023.
funFacts: Bennu is potentially hazardous - it may impact Earth in 2182.
OSIRIS-REx collected samples from Bennu's surface.
Its surface is rocky and boulder-covered, not smooth.
Bennu is a 'rubble pile' asteroid held together by gravity.

name: Ryugu
description: Ryugu is a diamond-shaped near-Earth asteroid. Japan's Hayabusa2 mission collected samples and returned them to Earth in 2020.
funFacts: Hayabusa2 collected samples from both surface and subsurface.
Ryugu has a top-like spinning shape.
Its surface is covered with large boulders.
Named after a dragon's palace in Japanese folklore.

name: Apophis
description: Apophis is a near-Earth asteroid that will pass extremely close to Earth in 2029 - closer than some satellites. It caused a brief scare when first discovered due to potential impact.
funFacts: On April 13, 2029, Apophis will pass within 31,000 km of Earth.
It will be visible to the naked eye during the 2029 flyby.
Named after the Egyptian god of chaos and destruction.
Initial calculations showed a 2.7% chance of impact in 2029.
discoveredBy: Roy Tucker, David Tholen, Fabrizio Bernardi

name: Itokawa
description: Itokawa is a peanut-shaped near-Earth asteroid. Japan's Hayabusa mission returned samples from Itokawa in 2010.
funFacts: First asteroid from which samples were returned to Earth.
Itokawa is a 'rubble pile' of loosely packed rocks.
Named after Hideo Itokawa, father of Japanese rocketry.
Its surface has almost no small craters due to seismic shaking.

name: Psyche
description: Psyche is a large metal-rich asteroid that may be the exposed core of a protoplanet. NASA's Psyche mission launched in 2023 to study it.
funFacts: Psyche may be worth $10 quintillion in metals.
It could be the core of a Mars-sized planet that lost its crust.
The Psyche spacecraft will arrive in 2029.
Named after the Greek goddess of the soul.
